title: CSS Pseudo-elements
subject: CSS
theory:
A CSS pseudo-element is used to style specified parts of an element.

*   `::before`: Inserts content BEFORE the content of the selected element.
*   `::after`: Inserts content AFTER the content of the selected element.
*   `::first-letter`: Styles the first letter of the text.
*   `::first-line`: Styles the first line of the text.

Double colon `::` is the modern syntax for pseudo-elements (vs single `:` for pseudo-classes).

common_mistakes.correction: ::before and ::after DO NOT Work without the `content` property, even if it's an empty string.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between specificities of pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements?
interview_questions.answer: They basically have the same specificity (0,0,1,0), similar to a class.

practice_problems.problem: Make the first letter of a paragraph 50px large (Drop Cap).

real_world_use_cases.description: Developers hide the default checkbox and use `::before` on a label to draw a custom box.

exam_notes: You can use the single-colon syntax :after for IE8 compatibility, but :: is preferred.
::selection styles text selected by the user.
summary: Pseudo-elements allow you to insert content via CSS and style parts of the DOM that don't exist as elements.
